Solving Maker-Breaker Games on 5-uniform
hypergraphs is PSPACEâ€‘complete
Finn Koepke (finnkoepke@outlook.com)
Abstract
Let (ğ‘‹, â„±) be a hypergraph. The Maker-Breaker game on (ğ‘‹, â„±) is a combinatorial game
between two players, Maker and Breaker. Beginning with Maker, the players take turns claiming
vertices from ğ‘‹ that have not yet been claimed. Maker wins if she manages to claim all vertices
of some hyperedge ğ¹âˆˆâ„±. Breaker wins if he claims at least one vertex in every hyperedge.
M. L. Rahman and Thomas Watson proved in 2021 that, even when only Maker-Breaker games
on 6-uniform hypergraphs are considered, the decision problem of determining which player has
a winning strategy is PSPACEâ€‘complete. They also showed that the problem is NLâ€‘hard when
considering hypergraphs of rank 5.
In this paper, we improve the latter result by showing that deciding who wins Maker-Breaker
games on 5-uniform hypergraphs is still a PSPACEâ€‘complete problem. We achieve this by
polynomial transformation from the problem of solving the generalized geography game on
bipartite digraphs with vertex degrees 3 or less, which is known to be PSPACEâ€‘complete.

(ğ‘‹ğ‘ƒ, â„±ğ‘ƒ, ğ‘¡) the game that ğ‘ƒ reduces to.

Given a pairing ğ¶, we can construct a pairing strategy for Breaker in the Maker-Breaker

By following this strategy, Breaker ensures that Maker cannot ever claim both squares of any

Generalized Geography
The game Geography is a word game in which two players take turns naming geographical
places. The starting word is fixed. For each place named, its first letter must be the same as
the last letter of the previous word. The players may not repeat words. If a player cannot think
of a valid word, they lose the game.
Example.
Alice and Bob agree to play Geography only with the names of countries. They choose the
starting word â€œLuxembourgâ€. Alice goes first and has to say â€œLuxembourgâ€, to which Bob
answers â€œGermanyâ€. Alice must now say â€œYemenâ€ as it is the only country starting with a
â€œyâ€. Bob replies with â€œNorwayâ€ and Alice loses the game as she has no valid moves.
Geography can be generalized to a combinatorial game given by a weakly connected digraph
ğº= (ğ‘‰, ğ´) and a starting vertex ğ‘ âˆˆğ‘‰. The set of vertices corresponds to the set of allowed
words, and each edge (ğ‘£, ğ‘¤) signifies that ğ‘¤ starts with the same letter ğ‘£ ends in. An instance
(ğº, ğ‘ ) of Generalized Geography is therefore played as follows:
Alice begins by marking the designated starting vertex ğ‘ . Then, starting with Bob, the two
players alternate taking turns marking a previously unmarked vertex. It must be one that has
an incoming edge from the previously marked vertex. The game ends when a player cannot
make a legal move; that player loses the game.
Notation.
Given a digraph (ğ‘‰, ğ´) and a vertex ğ‘£âˆˆğ‘‰, we let ğ›¿+(ğ‘£) be the set of outgoing edges of ğ‘£
and ğ›¿âˆ’(ğ‘£) be the set of incoming edges of ğ‘£. Also, we let ğ›¿(ğ‘£) â‰”ğ›¿âˆ’(ğ‘£) âˆªğ›¿+(ğ‘£) be the set of
all edges incident to ğ‘£.
Lemma 1.
The problem of deciding who wins an instance (ğº, ğ‘ ) of Generalized Geography is
PSPACEâ€‘complete even if we only consider the case where:
1. ğº is planar and bipartite.
2. Each vertex ğ‘£âˆˆğ‘‰(ğº) fulfills |ğ›¿(ğ‘£)| â‰¤3.
3. Each vertex ğ‘£âˆˆğ‘‰(ğº) âˆ–{ğ‘ } fulfills |ğ›¿+(ğ‘£)| âˆˆ{1, 2} and |ğ›¿âˆ’(ğ‘£)| âˆˆ{1, 2}.
4. For the starting vertex ğ‘ , we have |ğ›¿+(ğ‘ )| âˆˆ{1, 2} and |ğ›¿âˆ’(ğ‘ )| = 0.
This lemma was proven in [2] by reduction from the true quantified boolean formula decision
problem (TQBF). Even though points 3 and 4 were not explicitly stated, it is easy to verify that
the constructed digraph (see Figure 1 in [2]) always has those properties. All these properties,
besides planarity, will be very useful when constructing our Maker-Breaker game later.
Corollary 2.
The problem from LemmaÂ 1 remains PSPACEâ€‘complete even if we change point 4 such that
it requires ğ‘  to have out-degree exactly 1.
Proof.  Let (ğº, ğ‘ ) be an instance of Generalized Geography that fulfills the properties in
LemmaÂ 1, but where ğ‘  has out-degree 2. Let (ğ‘ , ğ‘£) and (ğ‘ , ğ‘¤) be the two outgoing edges of ğ‘ . We
can add two new vertices ğ‘¥1, ğ‘¥2 and replace the edges (ğ‘ , ğ‘£) and (ğ‘ , ğ‘¤) with the edges (ğ‘ , ğ‘¥1),
(ğ‘¥1, ğ‘¥2), (ğ‘¥2, ğ‘£) and (ğ‘¥2, ğ‘¤). We call this new graph ğº+.

We call an instance (ğº, ğ‘ ) of Generalized Geography convertible if it fulfills the requirements

Because ğº is weakly connected, choosing one of two colors for a single vertex yields a unique
2-coloring of ğº. Let ğ‘‰ğ´âŠ”ğ‘‰ğµ= ğ‘‰(ğº) be the unique 2-coloring of ğº with ğ‘ âˆˆğ‘‰ğµ. As every edge

Regular Play
Let (ğº, ğ‘ ) be a convertible instance of Generalized Geography, and let (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª) be its associated
Maker-Breaker game. Let ğ‘‰(ğº) = ğ‘‰ğ´âŠ”ğ‘‰ğµ be the unique bipartition of ğ‘‰(ğº) such that ğ‘ âˆˆğ‘‰ğµ.
For each vertex class, column 4 of TableÂ 1 shows its regular play sequences. For vertices

incoming edges. Otherwise, there is only one sequence.
We can now formally describe regular play in (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª). The game begins with ğ‘  being what
we call the active vertex. As long as there is an active vertex ğ‘£, its class determines what
happens next.
Case 1: ğ‘£âˆˆğ‘€1,2 âˆªğµ1,2
If ğ‘£âˆˆğ‘€1,2, Maker chooses one of the two lines of play given in TableÂ 1, row 1, column 4. If
ğ‘£âˆˆğµ1,2, Breaker chooses one of the two lines of play given in TableÂ 1, row 2, column 4. Maker
and Breaker play according to that line of play. Once these moves have been made, Maker will

Here, ğ‘£ has two incoming edges, ğ‘ and ğ‘. Let ğ‘’âˆˆ{ğ‘, ğ‘} be the edge that connects the previously
active vertex to ğ‘£, and let ğ‘= (ğ‘£, ğ‘¤) be the outgoing edge of ğ‘£.
â€¢ If ğ‘£ is active for the first time, depending on whether ğ‘’= ğ‘ or ğ‘’= ğ‘, Maker and Breaker
follow the first or second line of play in TableÂ 1, column 4 of ğ‘£â€™s class. At its end, Maker will
have claimed both joint squares of ğ‘. The next active vertex is ğ‘¤.
â€¢ If ğ‘£ was active once already, the class of ğ‘£ determines who will end up winning the game. The
moment ğ‘£ becomes active, it is Makerâ€™s turn and the squares ğ‘ğ‘’, ğ‘ğ‘’, ğ‘ğ‘, and ğ‘ğ‘ are already
claimed by Maker. There is a winning combination ğ¹âˆˆâ„±(ğ‘£) that contains all these squares
plus an interior square ğ‘¥. If ğ‘£âˆˆğ‘€2,1, ğ‘¥ is unclaimed. In that case, Maker claims ğ‘¥ and wins
immediately. If ğ‘£âˆˆğµ2,1, ğ‘¥ is already claimed by Breaker. In this case, there ceases to be an
active vertex.
Once there is no active vertex anymore, regular play entails Maker claiming arbitrary squares
and Breaker following the winning strategy provided to him via LemmaÂ 3.
Lemma 3.
If Maker and Breaker follow regular play in (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª), and there ceases to be an active vertex
because some ğ‘£âˆˆğµ2,1 became active for a second time, that position is Breakerâ€™s win.

To prove this Lemma, we need to first establish some invariants that hold while there is an
active vertex during regular play.
Invariants of regular play.
Let ğ‘ƒ be a position that occurs during regular play in (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª) while there is an active
vertex ğ‘£.
1. If it is Makerâ€™s turn in ğ‘ƒ, she will claim an interior square or an output square of ğ»(ğ‘£). If
it is Breakerâ€™s turn, he will claim an interior square of ğ»(ğ‘£).
2. For each vertex ğ‘¤ that was never active, and every square ğ‘âˆˆğ‘‹(ğ‘¤), one of these holds:
â€¢ The square ğ‘ is unclaimed in ğ‘ƒ.
â€¢ We have (ğ‘£, ğ‘¤) âˆˆğ´, ğ‘ is a joint square of that edge, and it is claimed by Maker.

Theorem 4.
If both players play perfectly while having to follow regular play in (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª), the outcome

loses the game. This change does not impact whether a given instance of Generalized Geography

We want to show that while there is an active vertex, regular play in (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª) is essentially

most recently marked vertex has more than one outgoing edge. During regular play of (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª),

In regular play, the winner is determined when a vertex ğ‘£ becomes active for a second time. If

PSPACEâ€‘completeness
We can now put the pieces together and prove the result we have been working towards.
Theorem 9.
Determining the winner of a Maker-Breaker game is a PSPACEâ€‘complete decision problem
even if we only allow games played on hypergraphs of rank 5.
Proof.  Let (ğº, ğ‘ ) be a convertible instance of Generalized Geography, and (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª) its
associated Maker-Breaker game. Combining LemmaÂ 5 with LemmaÂ 8 yields that one way for
Maker and Breaker to play perfectly in (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª) is to follow regular play. As a result, (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª)
is Makerâ€™s win if and only if it is also Makerâ€™s win when only perfect play is allowed. Adding
TheoremÂ 4, we obtain the result that (ğº, ğ‘ ) is Aliceâ€™s win if and only if (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª) is Makerâ€™s win.
Since (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª) can be constructed in linear time with respect to the size of ğº, we obtain
a polynomial transformation from the problem of solving convertible instances of generalized
geography to the problem of solving rank-5 Maker-Breaker games. Given CorollaryÂ 2, this means
that the latter problem is PSPACEâ€‘hard.
Solving general Maker-Breaker games is a problem in PSPACE [3]. Hence, solving rank-5
Maker-Breaker games is a PSPACEâ€‘complete problem.

Determining the winner of a Maker-Breaker game is a PSPACEâ€‘complete decision problem
even if we only allow games played on 5-uniform hypergraphs.
Proof.  Let (ğº, ğ‘ ) be a convertible instance of Generalized Geography, and (ğ‘‹, â„±, ğ”ª) its
associated Maker-Breaker game. In the proof of Corollary 17 in [4], it was demonstrated how

Conclusion
By polynomial transformation from the problem of determining the winner of a special case of
Generalized Geography, we could show that the problem of solving Maker-Breaker games on
5-uniform hypergraphs is also PSPACEâ€‘complete.
In [5], it was shown that the problem of solving Maker-Breaker games on hypergraphs of rank
3 or lower can be solved in polynomial time. This leaves us with an obvious open problem: How
difficult is solving Maker-Breaker games on hypergraphs of rank 4?

metadata.title: Solving Maker-Breaker Games on 5-uniform hypergraphs is PSPACE-complete
metadata.abstract:
Let $(X, \mathcal{F})$ be a hypergraph. The Maker-Breaker game on $(X,
\mathcal{F})$ is a combinatorial game between two players, Maker and Breaker.
Beginning with Maker, the players take turns claiming vertices from $X$ that
have not yet been claimed. Maker wins if she manages to claim all vertices of
some hyperedge $F \in \mathcal{F}$. Breaker wins if he claims at least one
vertex in every hyperedge.
  M. L. Rahman and Thomas Watson proved in 2021 that, even when only
Maker-Breaker games on 6-uniform hypergraphs are considered, the decision
problem of determining which player has a winning strategy is PSPACE-complete.
They also showed that the problem is NL-hard when considering hypergraphs of
rank 5.
  In this paper, we improve the latter result by showing that deciding who wins
Maker-Breaker games on 5-uniform hypergraphs is still a PSPACE-complete
problem. We achieve this by polynomial transformation from the problem of
solving the generalized geography game on bipartite digraphs with vertex
degrees 3 or less, which is known to be PSPACE-complete.
